Spectral Algorithms for Unique Games

Alexandra Kolla Microsoft Research.
Abstract

We give a new algorithm for Unique Games which is based on purely spectral techniques, in contrast to previous work in the area, which relies heavily on semidefinite programming (SDP). Given a highly satisfiable instance of Unique Games, our algorithm is able to recover a good assignment. The approximation guarantee depends only on the completeness of the game, and not on the alphabet size, while the running time depends on spectral properties of the Label-Extended graph associated with the instance of Unique Games.

We further show that on input the integrality gap instance of Khot and Vishnoi, our algorithm runs in quasi-polynomial time and decides that the instance if highly unsatisfiable. Notably, when run on this instance, the standard SDP relaxation of Unique Games fails. As a special case, we also re-derive a polynomial time algorithm for Unique Games on expander constraint graphs.

The main ingredient of our algorithm is a technique to effectively use the full spectrum of the underlying graph instead of just the second eigenvalue, which is of independent interest. The question of how to take advantage of the full spectrum of a graph in the design of algorithms has been often studied, but no significant progress was made prior to this work.

1 Introduction

A Unique Game is defined in terms of a constraint graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ), an integer k𝑘kitalic_k which is called the alphabet, a set of variables {xu}u∈Vsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑢𝑢𝑉\{x_{u}\}_{u\in V}{ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ∈ italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one for each vertex u𝑢uitalic_u, and a set of permutations (constraints) πu⁢v:[k]→[k]:subscript𝜋𝑢𝑣→delimited-[]𝑘delimited-[]𝑘\pi_{uv}:[k]\rightarrow[k]italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : [ italic_k ] → [ italic_k ], one for each edge (u,v)∈E𝑢𝑣𝐸(u,v)\in E( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ italic_E. An assignment to the variables (labeling) is said to satisfy the constraint on the edge (u,v)∈E𝑢𝑣𝐸(u,v)\in E( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ italic_E if πu⁢v⁢(xu)=xvsubscript𝜋𝑢𝑣subscript𝑥𝑢subscript𝑥𝑣\pi_{uv}(x_{u})=x_{v}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The edges are taken to be undirected and hence πu⁢v=(πv⁢u)−1subscript𝜋𝑢𝑣superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑣𝑢1\pi_{uv}=(\pi_{vu})^{-1}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The goal is to assign a value from the set [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k][ italic_k ] to each variable xusubscript𝑥𝑢x_{u}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT so as to maximize the number of satisfied constraints.

Khot [Kho02] conjectured that it is NP-hard to distinguish between the cases when almost all the constraints of a Unique Game are satisfiable and when very few of the constraints are satisfiable:

Conjecture 1.

(Unique Games Conjecture-UGC) For any constants ϵ,δ>0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta>0italic_ϵ , italic_δ > 0, there is a k⁢(ϵ,δ)𝑘italic-ϵ𝛿k(\epsilon,\delta)italic_k ( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ) such that for any k>k⁢(ϵ,δ)𝑘𝑘italic-ϵ𝛿k>k(\epsilon,\delta)italic_k > italic_k ( italic_ϵ , italic_δ ), it is NP-hard to distinguish between instances of Unique Games with alphabet size k𝑘kitalic_k where at least 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon1 - italic_ϵ fraction of constraints are satisfiable and those where at most δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ fraction of constraints are satisfiable.

There are two reasons which make UGC particularly intriguing. First, it is a well-balanced question. Despite continuous efforts to prove or disprove it, there is still no consensus regarding its validity. This seems to indicate that UGC is more likely to be resolved in the near future in contrast to the P vs. NP problem for example, for which it is widely believed that P≠\neq≠NP but current techniques have been unable to prove it. Second, as seen by a series of works, the truth of UGC implies that the currently best known approximation algorithms for many important computational problems have optimal approximation ratios. Since its origin, UGC has been successfully used to prove often optimal hardness of approximation results for several important NP-hard problems such as Min-2Sat-Deletion [Kho02], Vertex Cover [KR03], Maximum Cut [KKMO04] and non-uniform Sparsest Cut [CKK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT06, KV05]. In addition, in recent years, UGC has also proved to be intimately connected to the limitations of semidefinite programming (SDP). Making this connection precise, the authors in [Aus10] and [Rag08] show that if UGC is true, then for every constraint satisfaction problem (CSP) the best approximation ratio is given by a certain simple SDP.

Arguably, a seemingly strong reason for belief in UGC is the failure of several attempts to design efficient algorithms for Unique Games using current state-of-the-art techniques, such as linear and semidefinite programming (LP/SDP). Indeed, several works [KV05, RS09] show limitations of LPs and SDPs in solving Unique Games by exhibiting the existence of itegrality gap instances. Those are Unique Games instances that fool the SDP since, even though they have no good satisfying assignment, the respective SDP solution is high. The existence of such instances implies, in particular, that there is no hope for a “good” approximation algorithm based on those SDPs. Moreover, recently it was shown that solving Unique Games is at least as hard as another seemingly hard problem called the small set expansion problem [RS10]. Our work presents evidence that a different set of techniques might be more powerful when it comes to designing algorithms for Unique Games thus giving hope that such techniques can be used to potentially disprove UGC.

We present a purely spectral algorithm for Unique Games that finds highly satisfying assignments when they exist. The running time of our algorithm depends on spectral properties of the Label-Extended graph or the constraint graph associated with the instance of Unique Games. Our algorithm runs in polynomial or quasi-polynomial time for a large class of instances, including those where the standard SDP provably fails as well as instances where the constraint graph is an expander. At a high level, we show that given ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0italic_ϵ > 0, there is a δ=δ⁢(ϵ)𝛿𝛿italic-ϵ\delta=\delta(\epsilon)italic_δ = italic_δ ( italic_ϵ ) such that the algorithm is able to distinguish between the following two cases:

  • •

    YES case: There exists an assignment that satisfies (1−ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1-\epsilon)( 1 - italic_ϵ ) fraction of the constraints.

  • •

    NO case: Every assignment satisfies less that δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ fraction of the constraints.

In particular, our algorithm runs in quasi-polynomial time on input the SDP integrality gap instance as it appears in [KV05] (hereafter referred to as 𝒦⁢𝒱𝒦𝒱\mathcal{K}\mathcal{V}caligraphic_K caligraphic_V). We note that the authors in [KV05] roughly showed that, when run on a certain highly unsatisfiable instance of Unique Games, the standard SDP relaxation has very high objective value and consequently fails to distinguish between the two cases above. As another special case, our algorithm runs in polynomial time when the constraint graph is an expander (therefore re-deriving results similar to [AKK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT08] and [KT07]). Moreover, similarly to [AKK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT08, MM09, KT07, AIMS09], the performance of the algorithm does not depend on the alphabet size k𝑘kitalic_k.

Our main result is the following:

Theorem.

(Main) Let 𝒰=(G,M,k)𝒰𝐺𝑀𝑘\mathcal{U}=(G,M,k)caligraphic_U = ( italic_G , italic_M , italic_k ) be a (1−ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1-\epsilon)( 1 - italic_ϵ ) satisfiable instance of Unique Games on a d𝑑ditalic_d-regular graph G𝐺Gitalic_G with alphabet size k𝑘kitalic_k. Let M𝑀Mitalic_M be the adjacency matrix of the label-extended graph of G𝐺Gitalic_G. Let W𝑊Witalic_W be the space spanned by eigenvectors of M𝑀Mitalic_M that have eigenvalue greater than (1−γ)⁢d1𝛾𝑑(1-\gamma)d( 1 - italic_γ ) italic_d, for γ>8⁢ϵ𝛾8italic-ϵ\gamma>8\epsilonitalic_γ > 8 italic_ϵ. There is an algorithm that runs in time 2O⁢(γϵ⁢𝑑𝑖𝑚⁢(W))+𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦⁢(n⋅k)superscript2𝑂𝛾italic-ϵ𝑑𝑖𝑚𝑊𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦normal-⋅𝑛𝑘2^{O(\frac{\gamma}{\epsilon}\text{dim}(W))}+\text{poly}(n\cdot k)2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG dim ( italic_W ) ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + poly ( italic_n ⋅ italic_k ) and finds an assignment that satisfies at least (1−O⁢(ϵγ−8⁢ϵ+ϵ))1𝑂italic-ϵ𝛾8italic-ϵitalic-ϵ(1-O(\frac{\epsilon}{\gamma-8\epsilon}+\epsilon))( 1 - italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ - 8 italic_ϵ end_ARG + italic_ϵ ) ) fraction of the constraints.

We also show a similar theorem for the special case where all the constraints are of the form ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ-Max-Lin and the graph satisfies some special properties. That theorem is then used to derive the above-mentioned algorithm for expanders.

Our key contribution is a technique of effectively using the full spectrum and eigenvectors of the relevant graph rather than just the first few eigenvalues. Interestingly, prior to this work, researchers had often attempted to take advantage of the full spectrum of a graph in the design of approximation algorithms, but no significant progress was made. We believe that our techniques are of independent interest and could contribute to developing better algorithms for a number of other problems. In a recent breakthrough paper, Arora, Barak and Steurer [ABS10] used our main technique as a crucial building block in their sub-exponential time algorithm for arbitrary instances of Unique Games. Consequently, we believe that our results give evidence that spectral techniques might be a more powerful tool than SDPs for attacking and, potentially even disproving, the Unique Games Conjecture.

1.1 Comparison to Other Work on Unique Games

Several polynomial time approximation algorithms using linear and semidefinite programming have been developed for Unique Games on arbitrary graphs (see [Kho02], [Tre05], [GT06], [CMM06a], [CMM06b]). These algorithms start with an instance where the value of the SDP or LP relaxation is 1−ϵ1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon1 - italic_ϵ and round it to a solution with value ν𝜈\nuitalic_ν. Here, value of the game refers to the maximum fraction of satisfiable constraints. For ν>δ𝜈𝛿\nu>\deltaitalic_ν > italic_δ, this would give an algorithm to distinguish between the two cases. However, most of these algorithms give good approximations only when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ is very small (ϵ=O⁢(1/log⁡n)italic-ϵ𝑂1𝑛\epsilon=O(1/\log n)italic_ϵ = italic_O ( 1 / roman_log italic_n ) or ϵ=O⁢(1/log⁡k)italic-ϵ𝑂1𝑘\epsilon=O(1/\log k)italic_ϵ = italic_O ( 1 / roman_log italic_k )) and their approximation guarantee depends on the alphabet size k𝑘kitalic_k 111It might be good to think of k𝑘kitalic_k as O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) since this is the range of interest for most reductions.. For constant ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ, only the algorithm in [CMM06a] gives interesting parameters with ν≈k−ϵ/(2−ϵ)𝜈superscript𝑘italic-ϵ2italic-ϵ\nu\approx k^{-\epsilon/(2-\epsilon)}italic_ν ≈ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ϵ / ( 2 - italic_ϵ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We refer the reader to [CMM06a] for a comparison of parameters of various algorithms.

For some special cases of graphs, it has been shown that there are efficient algorithms that solve Unique Games. One such example is when the constraint graph is a spectral expander. In that case, the authors in [AKK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT08] (and later [MM09] with improved parameters) showed that one can find a highly satisfying assignment (with, say, ν≥90%𝜈percent90\nu\geq 90\%italic_ν ≥ 90 %) in polynomial time. Notably, the approximation guarantee of their algorithm depends on the expansion parameters of the graph rather than the alphabet size. As another example, the authors in [AIMS09] presented efficient algorithms for constraint graphs with large local expansion.

Compared to the previous papers, our algorithm uses purely spectral methods as opposed to linear or semidefinite programming and runs in time that depends on spectral properties of the constraint graph or the label-extended graph. The approximation guarantee does not depend on the size of the graph or the size of the alphabet and thus our algorithm always finds a good assignment when one exists. We note that, in an unpublished manuscript, Kolla and Tulsiani [KT07] developed a spectral algorithm that runs in polynomial time and finds highly satisfying assignments on expander constraint graphs.

1.2 Overview of Our Techniques: Recovering Solutions by Spectral Methods

Our basic approach for the Unique Games algorithm is exhaustive search in a subspace spanned by several eigenvectors of a graph associated with the Unique Games instance. We identify a “good” subspace which contains a vector that “encodes” a highly satisfying assignment and then exhaustively search for this vector in (a discretization of) the subspace as we explain below.

Let 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U be our Unique Games instance which is (1−ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1-\epsilon)( 1 - italic_ϵ ) satisfiable. One can think of this instance as “coming from” a completely satisfiable instance 𝒰~~𝒰\mathcal{\tilde{U}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG as follows: an adversary on input 𝒰~~𝒰\mathcal{\tilde{U}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG, picks an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ fraction of edges and changes the constraints on those edges so that the resulting instance 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U becomes (1−ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1-\epsilon)( 1 - italic_ϵ ) satisfiable. Let M𝑀Mitalic_M be (the adjacency matrix of) the graph corresponding to 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U and M~~𝑀\widetilde{M}over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG (the adjacency matrix of) the graph corresponding to 𝒰~~𝒰\mathcal{\tilde{U}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG. Assume, for simplicity, that these graphs are d𝑑ditalic_d-regular. We first observe that a characteristic vector yαsubscript𝑦𝛼y_{\alpha}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of a perfectly satisfying assignment α𝛼\alphaitalic_α for 𝒰~~𝒰\mathcal{\tilde{U}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG is an eigenvector of M~~𝑀\widetilde{M}over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG with eigenvalue d𝑑ditalic_d.

We next consider a space W𝑊Witalic_W which is the span of the eigenvectors of M𝑀Mitalic_M with eigenvalue very close to d𝑑ditalic_d and show that every characteristic vector yαsubscript𝑦𝛼y_{\alpha}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to some vector in W𝑊Witalic_W (in ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm).

Our algorithm simply looks at a set 𝒮⊆W𝒮𝑊\mathcal{S}\subseteq Wcaligraphic_S ⊆ italic_W of appropriately many candidate vectors and “reads-off” an assignment.

Recover-Solution𝒮⁢(𝒰)subscriptRecover-Solution𝒮𝒰\texttt{Recover-Solution}_{\mathcal{S}}(\mathcal{U})Recover-Solution start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_U )

  • •

    For each x∈𝒮𝑥𝒮x\in\mathcal{S}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_S, construct an assignment Lxsubscript𝐿𝑥L_{x}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by assigning to each vertex u𝑢uitalic_u, the index corresponding to the largest entry in the block (xu⁢1,…,xu⁢k)subscript𝑥𝑢1…subscript𝑥𝑢𝑘(x_{u1},\ldots,x_{uk})( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) i.e. Lx⁢(u)=arg⁡maxi⁡xu⁢isubscript𝐿𝑥𝑢subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑢𝑖L_{x}(u)=\arg\max_{i}{x_{ui}}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u ) = roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

  • •

    Out of all assignments Lxsubscript𝐿𝑥L_{x}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for x∈𝒮𝑥𝒮x\in\mathcal{S}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_S, choose the one satisfying the maximum number of constraints.

To choose 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S,we identify a set of nice vectors 𝒩⊆W𝒩𝑊\mathcal{N}\subseteq Wcaligraphic_N ⊆ italic_W such that the above algorithm works for any vector v𝑣vitalic_v close to some vector in 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}caligraphic_N. These are going to be the vectors that are close to the assignment eigenvectors. We then construct a set 𝒮⊆W𝒮𝑊\mathcal{S}\subseteq Wcaligraphic_S ⊆ italic_W of test vectors such that at least one vector v∈𝒮𝑣𝒮v\in\mathcal{S}italic_v ∈ caligraphic_S is close to a vector in 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}caligraphic_N. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S is simply an epsilon-net for W𝑊Witalic_W. Lastly, we go over all vectors in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S until we find v𝑣vitalic_v. The running time of the algorithm will depend on the size of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S which, for an appropriately defined epsilon-net, it is exponential in the dimension of W𝑊Witalic_W.

Certain “simple” graphs, including expander graphs and the Khot-Vishnoi instance, have only a few eigenvalues close to d𝑑ditalic_d and thus the dimension of W𝑊Witalic_W is small. Consequently, exhaustive enumeration in the subspace spanned by the corresponding eigenvalues will quickly find a good-enough assignment.

1.3 Organization of the Paper

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: in section 2 we give some preliminary notation and definitions that will be used in the rest of the paper. Section 3 contains the proofs of the main theorem above as well as of a theorem for the ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ-Max-Lin case. More specifically, we prove the main theorem in subsection 3.1. The proof of the theorem for the ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ-Max-Lin case appears in subsection 3.2. Subsection 3.3 contains the generalization of the main theorem for non-regular graphs. In section 4, we analyze our algorithm when run on the Khot-Vishnoi instance.

2.2 The Label-Extended Graph

2.4 The Spectrum of Cayley Graphs

For the purposes of this paper, we will use a generalized definition for Cayley graphs. For background on the standard definition and properties of Cayley graphs see, for example, [Kas02, Spi09].

The following appears in [KV05]. We give the informal statement here, for simplicity. We refer the reader to [KV05] for the full statement and details.

2.6 Additional Notation

For simplicity of the presentation, we will assume that G𝐺Gitalic_G is a regular graph, namely ∑vwu⁢v=dsubscript𝑣subscript𝑤𝑢𝑣𝑑\sum_{v}w_{uv}=d∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d for all nodes u𝑢uitalic_u. At the end of the next section, we show that the results can easily be generalized to non-regular graphs.

For the sake of convenience, in the rest of the paper we will often use the term eigenspace to refer to the space spanned by a set of eigenvectors that don’t necessarily have the same eigenvalue. The relevant set of eigenvectors that span this space will always be clear from the context. We use poly⁢(n)poly𝑛\text{poly}(n)poly ( italic_n ) to refer to some polynomial function in n𝑛nitalic_n.

We also use the following notation for the time needed to compute eigenvalues and eigenvectors:

Definition 7.

Let 𝒰=(G,M,k)𝒰𝐺𝑀𝑘\mathcal{U}=(G,M,k)caligraphic_U = ( italic_G , italic_M , italic_k ) be an instance of Unique Games on a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G on n𝑛nitalic_n nodes and with alphabet size k𝑘kitalic_k. Let M𝑀Mitalic_M be the adjacency matrix of the label-extended graph of G𝐺Gitalic_G. Let W𝑊Witalic_W be some space spanned by eigenvectors of M𝑀Mitalic_M. We denote by TW⁢(M)subscript𝑇𝑊𝑀T_{W}(M)italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_M ) the time needed to compute an eigenbasis and the corresponding eigenvalues of W𝑊Witalic_W. Note that TW⁢(M)subscript𝑇𝑊𝑀T_{W}(M)italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_M ) is polynomial in the dimension of M𝑀Mitalic_M, namely TW⁢(M)=𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦⁢(n⋅k)subscript𝑇𝑊𝑀𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦normal-⋅𝑛𝑘T_{W}(M)=\text{poly}(n\cdot k)italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_M ) = poly ( italic_n ⋅ italic_k ).

We also note that in the rest of this paper we use the terms “assignment” and “labeling” interchangeably.

3 Recovering Solutions by Spectral Methods

In this section, we will show how, given a (1−ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1-\epsilon)( 1 - italic_ϵ ) satisfiable instance of Unique Games 𝒰=(G,M,k)𝒰𝐺𝑀𝑘\mathcal{U}=(G,M,k)caligraphic_U = ( italic_G , italic_M , italic_k ) on graph G𝐺Gitalic_G and with alphabet size k𝑘kitalic_k, the eigenvectors of the label-extended graph M𝑀Mitalic_M may be used to recover good assignments. Corollary 10.

(Unique Games are Easy on Expanders) Let 𝒰=(G,M,k)𝒰𝐺𝑀𝑘\mathcal{U}=(G,M,k)caligraphic_U = ( italic_G , italic_M , italic_k ) be a (1−ϵ)1italic-ϵ(1-\epsilon)( 1 - italic_ϵ ) satisfiable Γnormal-Γ\Gammaroman_Γ-Max-Lin instance of Unique Games. We remark that the ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ-Max-Lin requirement is necessary for corollary 10. The proof fails to produce similar guarantee for the general case. This is due to the fact that the spectral properties of label-extended graphs that correspond to arbitrary Unique Games are poorly understood.

3.1 Proof of Theorem 8

We prove theorem 8 by combining two facts. First we show that characteristic vectors of good labelings have large projection onto the eigenspace of M𝑀Mitalic_M spanned by eigenvectors with large eigenvalues. Then we show that if M𝑀Mitalic_M has at most D𝐷Ditalic_D large eigenvalues then we can find a vector close (in ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-norm) to such a characteristic vector of a labeling in time exponential in D𝐷Ditalic_D, by looking at an appropriate epsilon-net for this eigenspace. Our proof is inspired by the approach that the authors in the unpublished manuscript [KT07] used in order to recover satisfying assignments on expanders.

Proof Overview. We define a completely satisfiable game 𝒰~=(G,M~,k)~𝒰𝐺~𝑀𝑘\mathcal{\widetilde{U}}=(G,\widetilde{M},k)over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG = ( italic_G , over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG , italic_k ) (with value 1) that “corresponds” to 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U as follows:

Those are the assignment eigenvectors, namely the characteristic vectors of the (perfectly) satisfying assignments of 𝒰~~𝒰\mathcal{\widetilde{U}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG (since they all have eigenvalue equal to d𝑑ditalic_d). We will first observe that every such eigenvector y𝑦yitalic_y is close to some vector in W𝑊Witalic_W, and the length of the projection of y𝑦yitalic_y onto W𝑊Witalic_W depends on ϵ,γitalic-ϵ𝛾\epsilon,\gammaitalic_ϵ , italic_γ. We then identify a set of nice vectors 𝒩⊆W𝒩𝑊\mathcal{N}\subseteq Wcaligraphic_N ⊆ italic_W such that the above algorithm works for any vector v𝑣vitalic_v close to some vector in 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}caligraphic_N. These are going to be the vectors that are close to the assignment eigenvectors. We then construct a set 𝒮⊆W𝒮𝑊\mathcal{S}\subseteq Wcaligraphic_S ⊆ italic_W of test vectors such that at least one vector v∈𝒮𝑣𝒮v\in\mathcal{S}italic_v ∈ caligraphic_S is close to a vector in 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}caligraphic_N. 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S is simply an epsilon-net for W𝑊Witalic_W. Lastly, we go over all vectors in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S until we find v𝑣vitalic_v. The running time of the algorithm will depend on the size of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S which, for an appropriately defined epsilon-net, it is exponential in the dimension of W𝑊Witalic_W.

3.1.2 Eigenspace Enumeration: Finding the Set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}caligraphic_S of Test Vectors

Our next step is to show that the search for a good assignment can be done in time exponential to the number of large eigenvalues of M𝑀Mitalic_M, namely the dimension of W𝑊Witalic_W.

Since we don’t know the y(ℒ)superscript𝑦ℒy^{(\mathcal{L})}italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_L ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (if we did, we would be done), and the space W𝑊Witalic_W contains infinitely many unit vectors, we cannot identify 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}caligraphic_N. To get around this, we discretize W𝑊Witalic_W with an appropriate epsilon-net. If we let w(0),…,w(dim⁢(W)−1)superscript𝑤0…superscript𝑤dim𝑊1w^{(0)},\ldots,w^{(\text{dim}(W)-1)}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( dim ( italic_W ) - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be an eigenbasis for W𝑊Witalic_W. 3.2 Proof of Theorem 9

Let θ>0𝜃0\theta>0italic_θ > 0 such that γ≥θ≥Ω⁢(ϵ⁢γ)𝛾𝜃Ωitalic-ϵ𝛾\gamma\geq\theta\geq\Omega(\epsilon\gamma)italic_γ ≥ italic_θ ≥ roman_Ω ( italic_ϵ italic_γ ). Let Y𝑌Yitalic_Y be the span of eigenvectors of M~~𝑀\widetilde{M}over~ start_ARG italic_M end_ARG with eigenvalue at least (1−γ)⁢d1𝛾𝑑(1-\gamma)d( 1 - italic_γ ) italic_d. In particular, Y𝑌Yitalic_Y contains all the assignment eigenvectors, namely the characteristic vectors of the (perfectly) satisfying assignments of 𝒰~~𝒰\mathcal{\widetilde{U}}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_U end_ARG (since they all have eigenvalue equal to d𝑑ditalic_d). Let Y⟂subscript𝑌perpendicular-toY_{\perp}italic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟂ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the orthogonal complement of Y𝑌Yitalic_Y.
For the proof, we will use theorem 8 together with a bound on the dimension of W. Roughly we show that the dimension of W𝑊Witalic_W is at most as large as the dimension of Y𝑌Yitalic_Y which, in turn, is at most k𝑘kitalic_k times the dimension of S(1−γ)subscript𝑆1𝛾S_{(1-\gamma)}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_γ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To conclude, we apply theorem 8 for the eigenspace W𝑊Witalic_W.

We will assume w.l.o.g that the graphs we are dealing with are connected. Otherwise, we apply the results to each connected component individually.

4 Solving Unique Games on the Khot-Vishnoi Instance

In this section, we show that, when run on the Khot-Vishnoi integrality gap instance, our main algorithm runs in quasi-polynomial time and correctly decides the (un)satisfiability of the instance. Namely, we show the following:

Our main algorithm (as in theorem 8) when given input the integrality gap instance of Khot and Vishnoi as described in the preliminaries section, with label-extended graph 𝒦⁢𝒱~n,ϵsubscriptnormal-~𝒦𝒱𝑛italic-ϵ\widetilde{\mathcal{K}\mathcal{V}}_{n,\epsilon}over~ start_ARG caligraphic_K caligraphic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, runs in time n𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦⁢(log⁡n)superscript𝑛𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦𝑛n^{\text{poly}(\log n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT poly ( roman_log italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and correctly decides that the instance is highly unsatisfiable.
